period_description: The prehistory of the Philippines covers the events prior to the written history of what is now the Philippines. The current demarcation between this period and the Early history of the Philippines is 21 April 900, which is the equivalent on the Proleptic Gregorian calendar for the date indicated on the Laguna Copperplate Inscription—the earliest known surviving written record to come from the Philippines. This period saw the immense change that took hold of the archipelago from Stone Age cultures, continuing on with gradual widening of trade until 900 and the first surviving written records.

list.media_caption: Jota caviteña by the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, ca 1970
list.media_credit: Photo from Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents
list.text_description: Spanish folk song dances like the fandango and jota are disseminated throughout the 18th century. Both are characterized by couple dancing and the use of castanets and guitars. Photo: Jota Caviteña as performed by the Bayanihan Dance Company, ca 1970. (Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Crosscurrents

list.media_caption: Rigodon de honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938
list.media_credit: Photo from Foto News 1938, Eli Guieb III Collection
list.text_description: English country dance (contredanse) becomes fashionable in French courts; along with gavotte, and rigaudon, it spreads throughout Europe. Photo: Rigodon de Honor at Malacañan with Commonwealth President Manuel L. Quezon and guests, 1938. (Foto News 1938, Eli Guieb III Collection)

period_description: The recorded history of the Philippines begins with the creation of the Laguna Copperplate Inscription (LCI) in 900, the first written document found in an ancient Philippine language. The inscription itself identifies the date of its creation, and on its deciphering in 1992 moved the boundary between Philippine history and prehistory back 600 years. Prior to the LCI, the earliest record of the Philippine Islands corresponded with the arrival of Ferdinand Magellan in 1521. Magellan's arrival marks the beginning of the Spanish colonial period.

list.text_description: UST Salinggawi wins the UAAP Cheerdance Competition for five consecutive years since 2002. They will be defeated the following year by UP PEP Squad, its closest rival. Photo: UST Salinggawi, 2015 (Efigenio Toledo IV)

list.media_caption: First significant batch of Filipino dancers, including Leonor Orosa-Goquingco and Rosalia Merino-Santos, taught by Luva Adameit during the American period
list.article_title: Dance 1927 Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School
list.text_description: Polish choreographer Luva Adameit aka Madame Adameit (1895-48) establishes the Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School in Manila. Her students include Leonor Orosa, Remedios de Oteyza, Rosalia Merino, Inday Gaston, Joji Felix, Chloe Cruz, Pacita Madrigal, and Fely Franquelli. (Photo from Rosalia Merino-Santos Collection)

period_description: In 1521, Ferdinand Magellan, a Portuguese explorer who was serving the Spanish crown, landed in Samar Island on his voyage to circumvent the globe. He explored the islands and named it Archipelago of San Lazaro. Magellan was killed during a rebellion led by a Datu named Lapu Lapu in Mactan Island. Spain continued to send expeditions to the island for financial gain and on the fourth expedition, Commander Ruy Lopez de Villalobos, named the islands: Philippines, after Prince Philip (later King Philip II), heir to the Spanish throne. Spain ruled the Philippines for 356 years.

list.media_caption: Trudl Dubsky-Zipper in “Mountain King’s Daughter” from Peer Gynt Suite
list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of Basilio Esteban Villaruz
list.text_description: Viennese dancer-teacher-choreographer Trudl Dubsky (in photo) teaches modern dance at the Academy of Music and foreign dances at the University of the Philippines. (Photo from Steve Villaruz Collection)

list.media_caption: Mir-i-nisa, Dance Theater Philippines, CCP, Manila, 1969
list.text_description: Mir-i-nisa is the first Filipino ballet presented during the inaugural season of the CCP, choreographed by Julie Borromeo and Felicitas Layag-Radaic. (CCP Collection)

period_description: The Spanish-American war which started in Cuba, changed the history of the Philippines. On May 1, 1898, the Americans led by U.S. Navy Admiral George Dewey, in participation of Emilio Aguinaldo, attacked the Spanish Navy in Manila Bay. Faced with defeat, the Philippines was ceded to the United States by Spain in 1898 after a payment of US$ 20 million to Spain in accordance with the 'Treaty of Paris' ending the Spanish-American War. In accordance with the Tydings-McDuffie Act of 1934, The Philippines was given independence on July 4, 1946 and the Republic of the Philippines was born.

list.media_caption: Street dance during the Kasaysayan ng Lahi parade, CCP, Manila, 1974
list.media_credit: Photo from National Media Production Center
list.text_description: The highlight of the inauguration of Folk Arts Theater is a spectacular street parade with streetdancing titled Kasaysayan ng Lahi. (Photo from National Media Production Center)

list.media_caption: Nonong Pedero and Bienvenido Lumbera’s Tales of the Manuvu, Ballet Philippines, CCP, 1977
list.media_credit: Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection
list.text_description: Tales of the Manuvu, a rock opera ballet in five parts based on indigenous myths and tales is staged by Alice Reyes at the CCP with script and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera and music by Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth. (Photo from Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

period_description: This article covers the history of the Philippines from the recognition of independence in 1946 to the end of the presidency of Diosdado Macapagal, which covered much of the Third Republic of the Philippines which ended on January 17, 1973 with the ratification of the 1973 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines. When the Congress of the Philippines was convened in 1945, the legislators elected in 1941 chose Manuel Roxas as Senate President. In the April 23, 1946 election, Roxas won 54 percent of the vote. Roxas became the first president of the new republic.

list.media_caption: Tatlong Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, Ballet Manila, Aliw Theater, Manila, 2015
list.text_description: Ballet Manila presents Tatlong Kwento ni Lola Basyang with choreography by Osias Barroso, Lisa Macuja-Elizalde, and Tony Fabella. (Photo by Erica Jacinto)

list.media_caption: A version of the escotis, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Manila, ca 1970
list.media_credit: Photo from Bayanihan Dance Company Collection
list.text_description: Maestro Appiani, an Italian choreographer and dance teacher, forms the Compañia Infantil de Baile to perform in theaters like the Teatro de Binondo. For over a decade, he teaches ballroom dancing routines, among them quadrilles like the gavotte and rigodon, the redova, and the schottische, performed here by a dancer from the Bayanihan Dance Company, ca 1970. (Photo from Bayanihan Dance Company Collection)

period_description: The history of the Philippines, from 1965–1986, covers the presidency of Ferdinand Marcos, also known as the Ferdinand Marcos administration. The Marcos era includes the final years of the Third Republic (1965–1972), the Philippines under martial law (1972–1981), and the majority of the Fourth Republic (1981–1986). By its end, the country was experiencing a debt crisis, extreme poverty, and severe underemployment.

list.media_caption: Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa performing her choreography of langka budjang (female martial dance) using a fan, Seoul, Korea, 1988
list.media_credit: Photo from Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa Collection
list.text_description: The Tausug and Sama perform the langka dances, which resemble the ancient martial arts in Indonesia. Both are based on mastery of the self and alignment with the spiritual dimension.

list.media_caption: Sama women performing the igal or pangalay, Busbus, Jolo, 1976
list.media_credit: Photo from Joseph Fortin, CCP Collection
list.text_description: Pangalay or igal, a pre-Islamic and pre-Christian dance form similar to dance traditions in Cambodia, Indonesia, and other Asian countries, is performed by natives of the Sulu Archipelago. Photo: Sama women performing the pangalay in Jolo,1976. (Joseph Fortin, CCP Collection)

period_description: The world’s eye was on the Philippines after it successfully toppled down almost a decade of dictatorship rule through a peaceful demonstration tagged as the EDSA People’s Power Revolution. After the widowed wife of former Senator Benigno 'Ninoy' Aquino, Sr. was elected into office, President Corazon Cojuangco-Aquino faced both economic and political problems of the country. She was the 11th president of the Philippines and the first woman to become president of the country. It was not an easy task since the country’s economic condition was in its worse state since 1982.

list.text_description: The rigodon de honor is performed in Malacañan with the new national officials.
